content: The Act titled "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Special rules apply, including reducing the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence by the excluded amount. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes certain discharged indebtedness from gross income, with exceptions for loans not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. There are specific rules for determining qualified principal residence indebtedness and coordinating with other sections of the tax code. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes certain discharged indebtedness from gross income, with exceptions for loans not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. Coordination amendments include prioritizing principal residence exclusion over insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. Effective date for these changes is January 1, 2007. SEC. 3. Extension of mortgage insurance premiums treated as interest until December 31, 2010. Effective for payments after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4. Alternative tests for qualifying as cooperative housing corporation. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to define a cooperative housing corporation meeting specific requirements related to income, property usage, and expenditures for the taxable year. The amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act, benefiting tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. This section adds a new section to the Internal Revenue Code, SEC. 139B, which exempts benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and qualified payments. Deductions and expenses are subject to limitations to avoid double benefits. Qualified state and local tax benefits refer to tax reductions provided for services as a volunteer. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of a qualified volunteer emergency response organization and what constitutes a qualified payment for services provided. It states that a qualified payment is any payment provided by a State or political division for services rendered, with a maximum limit of $30 per month. The organization must be organized to provide firefighting or emergency medical services and be required to furnish these services by a written agreement with the State or political subdivision. The section discusses the termination of the application of certain tax provisions for taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant part. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Amendment made to clarify student housing eligibility for low-income housing credit. The amendment in section 7 applies the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion to certain post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment in section 7 applies a special rule for certain sales by surviving spouses within 2 years of their spouse's death, increasing the capital gains exclusion to $500,000. This amendment applies to sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to extend the time limitation for filing partnership returns to 12 months and increase the penalty amount to $85. Additionally, there are limitations on disclosing taxpayer returns to certain entities, ensuring that sensitive information is protected. The amendment made by this subsection regarding the time limitation for filing partnership returns and penalties shall take effect on the enactment date of this Act. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to returns required to be filed after the enactment date of this Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section imposing penalties for failure to file S corporation returns. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 includes a fine of $85 per month for each shareholder, up to a maximum of 12 months, unless reasonable cause is shown. The penalty is assessed against the S corporation and is not subject to deficiency procedures. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is not subject to deficiency procedures. A fine of $85 per month per shareholder, up to 12 months, is imposed unless reasonable cause is shown. The amendments made by this section apply to S corporation returns required to be filed after the enactment of this Act. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
